review: I was very curious about the Chromecast and I think that as a technology, it's very promising. The only problem is that the ecosystem is not yet fully supported. As many have pointed out, Amazon's Prime Instant videos are currently not directly supported. Granted, there are ways to work around, it's not at the easy usability level that's needed for mainstream use.In addition, it would be helpful if there's an easier way to send stored videos to Chromecast using a phone as the controller. For example, use a phone to browse videos and photos stored on a home computer, send the content to Chromecast from the phone and then go about your business on the phone.There are apps out there (some fairly good, such as RealPlayer Cloud, that can send videos that's local to the phone to Chromecast), some easy things like displaying photos on the phone via Chromecast should be built in. You will need to purchase an app similar to Avia in order to do that.Overall, for the price, it's great. It's very likely that Google is not making much money on the sales of the hardware, since the cost to build it is probably close to the $35 retail price. They of course benefit by others using Youtube and Android and other activities on Chromecast, so the few bucks per unit is probably not that big a deal for them.Once there's a more wider support for this, and this becomes mainstream, I think this will be a much better product. But if you are not a techie, move along, there's nothing to see here.
